title: Trump’s Single Stroke of Brilliance
abstract: His initiative has been the key to much of his success, but lacking any sense of prudence, he does not understand the difference between a risk and a gamble.

title: U.S. Sidelines Lawyers Who Doubted Their Own Case on Congestion Pricing
abstract: The Trump administration replaced lawyers who had exposed flaws in its legal battle over New York City’s congestion pricing program.

title: Trump’s Approval Rating Has Been Falling Steadily, Polling Average Shows
abstract: President Trump’s approval rating has sunk to about 45 percent, down from 52 percent one week after he took office.

title: Courts Block Trump From Withholding School Funds Over D.E.I., for Now
abstract: In three cases, federal judges paused the administration’s effort to cut off money from public schools with diversity and equity programs.

title: How Four Democrats Who Saved the Party Before Would Do It Again
abstract: How Democrats found their way out of the political wilderness once before, and how they could do it again now.

title: 17 Ways to Cut Your Risk of Stroke, Dementia and Depression All at Once
abstract: A new study identified overlapping factors that affect your odds of developing these brain diseases late in life.

title: On Major Economic Decisions, Trump Blinks, and Then Blinks Again
abstract: President Trump has said his punishing tariffs would force companies to build factories in the United States. But it is far from clear that they will have the effects he predicted.

title: Russia Pummels Kyiv, Prompting Rare Rebuke From Trump
abstract: The attack, which killed at least 12 people, was the deadliest on Ukraine’s capital in nearly a year. President Trump called on President Vladimir V. Putin to “STOP!” in a post on social media.

title: This Is the Hole the Anti-Woke Right Fell Into
abstract: DeSantis walked so that Trump could run.

title: A Beleaguered Hegseth Wanders Into His Forever War
abstract: The operation in Yemen has sent the Trump administration into an exorbitant, potentially escalatory spiral.

title: Tiger Woods and Vanessa Trump Make More Sense Together Than You Think
abstract: The official Instagram announcement ritual felt odd, but the pairing might not be.

title: A Stunning New Pool in Central Park Helps Heal Old Wounds
abstract: The $160 million Davis Center, with upgrades to six bucolic acres and a lake, writes a new chapter for the Harlem end of the park.

title: Kristi Noem’s Handbag Was Snatched From Beneath Her Chair, D.H.S. Says
abstract: Ms. Noem “could feel this person as they snatched her bag,” a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security said.

title: Prelude to a Funeral
abstract: A single image captures the subtle changes in how the Roman Catholic Church buries a pope.

title: Trump Takes a Major Step Toward Seabed Mining in International Waters
abstract: A new executive order pits the United States against the rest of the world over the question of who can exploit mineral resources in shared waters.

title: What Elon Musk Didn’t Budget For: Firing Workers Costs Money, Too
abstract: An expert on the federal work force estimates that the speed and chaos of Mr. Musk’s cuts to the bureaucracy will cost taxpayers $135 billion this fiscal year.

title: Stocks Extend Gains as Investors Weigh Fed Rates and Tariff Talk
abstract: After an early wobble, markets resumed rising after Chinese officials contradicted suggestions from President Trump and others about tariff negotiations.

title: U.S. Texts Barnard Employees and Asks if They Are Jewish
abstract: A questionnaire from a federal commission also inquired about whether professors and other college staff members had been harassed.

title: They Stole a Quarter-Billion in Crypto and Got Caught Within a Month
abstract: How luxury cars, $500,000 bar tabs and a mysterious kidnapping attempt helped investigators unravel the heist of a lifetime.

title: They Caught the Flu, and Never Came Home
abstract: The virus leads to an estimated 36,000 deaths in the United States each season — many of them so sudden that families are left reeling.

title: Trump Officials Blame Mistake for Setting Off Confrontation With Harvard
abstract: An official on the administration’s antisemitism task force told the university that a letter of demands had been sent without authorization.

title: Hegseth Said to Have Shared Attack Details in Second Signal Chat
abstract: The defense secretary sent sensitive information about strikes in Yemen to an encrypted group chat that included his wife and brother, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Larry David: My Dinner With Adolf
abstract: When a private meeting goes unexpectedly.

title: A Startling Admission From a G.O.P. Senator: ‘We Are All Afraid’
abstract: Lisa Murkowski, a longtime senator from Alaska and an independent voice in an increasingly tribal party, has been the rare Republican on Capitol Hill willing to criticize President Trump’s actions.

title: Kristi Noem’s Bag, With Security Badge and $3,000, Is Stolen
abstract: The homeland security secretary was dining at a Washington, D.C., restaurant. She also lost her passport and keys.

title: ‘60 Minutes’ Chief Resigns in Emotional Meeting: ‘The Company Is Done With Me’
abstract: The news program has faced mounting pressure from both President Trump and its corporate ownership at Paramount, the parent company of CBS News.

title: Francis, the First Latin American Pope, Dies at 88
abstract: After decades of conservative leadership, Francis tried to reset the course of the Roman Catholic Church, emphasizing inclusion and care for the marginalized over doctrinal purity.

title: What’s Happening Is Not Normal. America Needs an Uprising That Is Not Normal.
abstract: It will take a concerted effort by every sector of our society to respond to Trumpism’s threat.

title: Who Will Be the Next Pope? Here Are Some Possible Contenders.
abstract: Experts say there isn’t a single front-runner, but several names have been cited as indications of which direction the Roman Catholic Church might take.

title: The Trump Billionaires Who Run the Economy and the Things They Say
abstract: “You have to laugh to keep from crying,” one Republican pollster said about recent comments by the billionaires on the stock market, retirement funds and Social Security.

title: Head of I.R.S. Is Ousted in Treasury’s Power Struggle With Elon Musk
abstract: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent complained to President Trump that the acting commissioner had been installed without his knowledge.

title: White House Assesses Ways to Persuade Women to Have More Children
abstract: Baby bonuses and menstrual cycle classes are among the ideas pitched to Trump aides as they consider plans to try boosting the birthrate.

title: Six Men Are Charged After Woman Was Dragged From Idaho Town Hall
abstract: The plainclothes guards were involved in the forcible removal of a woman from a meeting hosted by local Republicans in Coeur d’Alene, prosecutors said.

title: Trump Pressures Ukraine to Accept a Peace Plan That Sharply Favors Russia
abstract: The U.S. proposal would freeze territory along the current front lines of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which Ukraine has rejected.

title: How 13 Independent Voters Who Backed Trump Think He Is Doing So Far
abstract: The participants discuss how they think Trump’s second term is going.

title: An Immigrant Held in U.S. Custody ‘Simply Disappeared’
abstract: The Venezuelan man did not appear on a list of people sent to a prison in El Salvador, and his family and friends had no idea of his whereabouts.

title: Judge Rules Against Trump Administration on Passport Changes
abstract: A group of transgender plaintiffs sued President Trump and the State Department over a new rule prohibiting passports from including a gender different from the sex listed on an original birth certificate.

title: Harvard Sues Trump Administration Over Threats to Cut Funding
abstract: Harvard’s lawsuit comes after the administration sought to force the university to comply with a list of demands by cutting billions in federal funding the school receives.

title: Under Hegseth, Chaos Prevails at the Pentagon
abstract: The defense secretary’s inner circle is in disarray, and distrust is growing among civil servants and senior military officials.

title: An Age of Extinction Is Coming. Here’s How to Survive.
abstract: Everything is under threat. What you care about can make it to the other side.

title: Val Kilmer, Film Star Who Played Batman and Jim Morrison, Dies at 65
abstract: A wide-ranging leading man who earned critical praise, he was known to be charismatic but unpredictable. At one point he dropped out of Hollywood for a decade.

title: Trump Administration Will Freeze $2 Billion After Harvard Refuses Demands
abstract: Federal officials said they would freeze the money after Harvard said it would not submit to requests to overhaul hiring and report international students who break rules.

title: Hillary Clinton: How Much Dumber Will This Get?
abstract: The Signal group chat is only the latest in a string of self-inflicted wounds by the new administration.

title: 10 Small Things Neurologists Wish You’d Do for Your Brain
abstract: Easy everyday habits can help keep you sharp. And it’s never too late to start them.

title: The Secret History of the War in Ukraine
abstract: This is the untold story of America’s hidden role in Ukrainian military operations against Russia’s invading armies.

title: Cory Booker Condemns Trump’s Policies in Longest Senate Speech on Record
abstract: The New Jersey senator spent much of his speech, which ended after more than 25 hours, assailing the Trump administration. He eclipsed Strom Thurmond’s filibuster of a civil rights bill in 1957.

title: Wisconsin Supreme Court Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2025 Wisconsin spring elections.

title: Astronomers Detect a Possible Signature of Life on a Distant Planet
abstract: Further studies are needed to determine whether K2-18b, which orbits a star 120 light-years away, is inhabited, or even habitable.

title: Suspect Charged in Arson at Pennsylvania Governor’s Mansion
abstract: A man was charged with setting fire to the residence, forcing Gov. Josh Shapiro and his family to flee. Investigators said they found beer bottles with gasoline inside the house.

title: He Was Held Captive in His Room for Decades. Then He Set It on Fire.
abstract: Firefighters found a 32-year-old man who weighed 68 pounds. The police say his stepmother locked him away when he was 12.

title: Supreme Court Sides With Wrongly Deported Migrant
abstract: A trial judge had ordered the Trump administration to take steps to return the migrant, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, from a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: How to Protect Your Retirement Savings Now as Markets Plunge
abstract: If you’re within five years of retiring, either before or after, you’re at your most vulnerable financially. Here are steps to weather the volatility.

title: The Leaked Signal Chat, Annotated
abstract: The chat’s contents, which were obtained by The Atlantic after its editor in chief was added to the Signal group, provide a revealing look at private conversations between top Trump administration officials.

title: Have We Been Thinking About A.D.H.D. All Wrong?
abstract: With diagnoses at a record high, some experts have begun to question our assumptions about the condition — and how to treat it.

title: Mass Protests Across the Country Show Resistance to Trump
abstract: Demonstrators packed the streets in cities and towns to rail against government cutbacks, financial turmoil and what they viewed as attacks on democracy.

title: Trump’s Crimea Proposal Would End a Decade of U.S. Resistance
abstract: A new U.S. peace plan offered to Russia and Ukraine proposes American recognition of the peninsula, which Moscow seized in 2014.

title: Trump Urges Russia to ‘STOP!’ After Deadly Attack on Ukraine’s Capital
abstract: President Trump also sought to divert blame should negotiations fall apart, a sign that he is perhaps more pessimistic about a deal than he was when he took office in January.

title: Lawyers Seek Return of Migrants Deported Under Wartime Act
abstract: An updated lawsuit filed in Washington was the latest in a flurry of suits challenging the Trump administration’s use of the Alien Enemies Act to send migrants to a prison in El Salvador.

title: Markets Rise on Hints of Easing Trade Tensions
abstract: Stocks were pointing toward a fourth straight positive trading session.

title: Why Did a Charity Tied to Casey DeSantis Suddenly Get a $10 Million Boost?
abstract: The Hope Florida Foundation quietly gave the money to two nonprofit political committees that helped Gov. Ron DeSantis and his allies defeat a ballot measure.

title: The Zuckerbergs Founded Two Bay Area Schools. Now They’re Closing.
abstract: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan, opened the schools to help communities of color. Some families wonder if the shutting of the schools is related to his D.E.I. retrenchment.

title: Where Bruce Lee Practiced on the Roof, a Shrine to Old Hong Kong Rises
abstract: At a formerly grand hotel where the famed martial arts star once stayed, a group of collectors is trying to preserve vestiges of the city’s past as its political identity changes.

title: Penn Station’s Not-So-Secret Other Life: The People’s Dance Studio
abstract: Smooth floors. Public restrooms. A built-in audience: The lower level of Moynihan Hall doubles as a rehearsal space for a variety of dance groups, including K-pop, salsa and Brazilian Zouk.

title: My Oscar for ‘No Other Land’ Didn’t Protect Me From Violence
abstract: Hamdan Ballal won an Oscar for co-directing “No Other Land,” then went home to the West Bank and was attacked and arrested.

title: Israel Acknowledges Second Deadly Attack on Aid Workers in Gaza
abstract: In a rare apology to the United Nations, Israel said its forces had struck a U.N. compound in Gaza with tank fire. A Bulgarian aid worker was killed.

title: Why Greater Toronto Could Decide Who Wins Canada’s Election
abstract: The Conservatives had enjoyed a lead over Liberals in the region largely because of rising housing and food costs. But President Trump’s tariffs have shifted the equation.

title: Robert S. Douglas, Founder of the Black Dog, Dies at 93
abstract: The logo for his tavern on Martha’s Vineyard transformed a black Labrador into an international emblem for summertime.

title: Florida Democratic Party Is ‘Dead,’ State Senator Says as He Leaves It
abstract: State Senator Jason Pizzo, the Democratic minority leader, announced in a floor speech that he was leaving the party.

title: The Things I Can Only Write in English
abstract: Writing in a second language can feel unnatural, but it presents a new way for writers to understand who they are — and how they fit into the world.

title: The Trump Victim I Can’t Stop Thinking About
abstract: It’s a moral imperative to try to rescue people like Andry Hernández Romero.

title: A Mistake in a New York Court Exposes the Truth About Trump’s Legal Strategy
abstract: The episode of the inadvertent court filings in the New York congestion-pricing case embodies the full range of the Trump administration’s incompetence.

title: We Are at Peak ‘Yep’ and It’s Wonderful
abstract: If there’s one thing we can agree on, it’s that we have many ways to agree.

title: Why ‘Vladimir, STOP!’ Won’t Stop Vladimir
abstract: On Wednesday Trump complained about Zelensky. On Thursday, Putin. The two messages illustrate why he’s struggling to end the war.

title: Kennedy’s Dangerous Autism Claims
abstract: Readers, including some with autism, rebut Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s statements. Also: President Trump vs. universities; Emanuel Ax’s plea.

title: Lydia Polgreen on Why Trump’s ‘Deportation Regime’ Is Actually Not Going Well
abstract: And what happens when your country becomes a place people no longer want to come to.

title: Can the Catholic Church Quit the Culture Wars?
abstract: The challenges for Catholicism in the modern world.

title: The Left Keeps Getting It Wrong on Crime
abstract: As more vigorous law enforcement has reduced crime, progressives are still trying to eliminate tools that have made the police more effective.

title: The World Seems to Be Surrendering to Climate Change
abstract: The state of the climate future, Part I.

title: How I Describe Myself Politically These Days
abstract: America needs to figure out how to dominate the industries of the future. Call me a “Waymo Democrat.”

title: A Republican Senator Says It: ‘We Are All Afraid’
abstract: Readers react to the startling admission by Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska. Also: Private prisons for immigrants; noise in a Queens neighborhood.

title: The Ugly Historical Echoes of Kennedy’s Comments on Autism
abstract: Kennedy implies that disabled people are a taxpayer burden.

title: After Pope Francis: A Round Table With David French
abstract: Three religious thinkers on the state of Catholicism.

title: The Very American Roots of Trumpism
abstract: The historian Steven Hahn puts Trumpism in the context of America’s long history of illiberalism.

title: Gov. Josh Shapiro: Finding Moral Clarity After an Arsonist’s Attack
abstract: This level of violence has to stop.

title: One Way to Keep Trump’s Authoritarian Fantasy From Becoming Our Reality
abstract: Trump wants you to think resistance is futile. It is not.

title: When the Supreme Court Spoke With One Voice
abstract: The federal judiciary is being forced to confront a fundamental question: What to do when its orders are defied?

title: Sign Up for the Science Times Newsletter
abstract: Every week, we’ll bring you stories that capture the wonders of the human body, nature and the cosmos.

title: Federal Officials Promise to Restore Funding to Women’s Health Initiative
abstract: The decades-long research effort has contributed to thousands of research papers, altering medical care for women around the world.

title: Trump Cuts Threaten Agency Running Meals on Wheels
abstract: A tiny division responsible for overseeing services for people with disabilities and older Americans is being dismantled as part of an overhaul by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary.

title: Leaders of Mental Health Giant Promised Big Bonuses to Deal With Federal Investigations
abstract: Acadia Healthcare’s chief executive was awarded a $1.8 million bonus to respond to “unprecedented governmental inquiries” into allegations of holding psychiatric patients against their will.

title: A Planned E.U. Rule Has Coffee Growers in Ethiopia Scrambling
abstract: The measure will require geolocation data to show that beans aren’t linked to deforestation. Farmers say they need more time to prepare.

title: New Study Could Bolster Climate Laws to Make Polluters Pay
abstract: Vermont was the first state to try to hold polluters accountable for climate disasters. New research aims to assign specific responsibility.

title: Tariffs on China Aren’t Likely to Rescue U.S. Medical Gear Industry
abstract: The few domestic companies that still make protective gear for health care workers have clamored for federal intervention. But they worry President Trump’s trade war with China won’t help.

title: The Latest Battleground for Luxury Tourism: Albania’s Adriatic Coast
abstract: Two major proposals led by Jared Kushner and a new airport championed by the Albanian government focus on an area prized for its biodiversity. Are they a sign of things to come?

title: Glimpses of the Final Frontier at the American Museum of Natural History
abstract: Stranded astronauts and celebrity space tourism have piqued interest in space — and a photography exhibition in the museum is making the most of it.

title: Almost Half of Americans Breathe Unhealthy Air, Report Finds
abstract: Weakening or rolling back longstanding environmental regulations would worsen the problem, the American Lung Association assessment says.

title: Birthrates Languish in Record Lows, C.D.C. Reports
abstract: Despite a 1 percent increase in 2024, U.S. birthrates remained in a historic slump, a trend that worries demographers and cultural critics.

title: Measles Surge in Southwest Is Now the Largest Single Outbreak Since 2000
abstract: Growing case numbers suggest that the national total will surpass that seen during the last large outbreak in 2019.

title: Sex Hormones Are Brain Hormones. What Does This Mean for Treating Brain Diseases?
abstract: A growing understanding of how “reproductive” hormones sculpt the brain could transform the management of neurological conditions.

title: Suicides and Rape at a Prized Mental Health Center
abstract: Timberline Knolls, a mental health center owned by Acadia Healthcare, skimped on staff. Then came a series of tragedies.

title: Maryland Protected Nearly a Third of Its Land, and It’s Reaching for More
abstract: Nine states have set goals to conserve 30 percent of their land by 2030. Maryland got there first.

title: In Indiana, Putting Up Solar Panels Is Doing God’s Work
abstract: A cluster of evangelical groups in the state is pushing for environmental action. Leaders say they’re following the biblical mandate to care for creation.

title: How a Funeral Director Brought Wind Power to Rural Missouri
abstract: Every year for nearly two decades, the small city of Rock Port has been producing more electricity from wind energy than it needs.

title: Fighting Louisiana Floodwaters With Patches of Green
abstract: Simple, affordable initiatives like rain gardens are helping to soak up water in New Orleans.

title: Herbert J. Gans, 97, Dies; Upended Myths of Urban and Suburban Life
abstract: A leading sociologist, he explored American society up close — living in a Levittown at one point — to gain insight into issues of race, class, the media and even the Yankees.

title: E.P.A. Set to Cancel Grants Aimed at Protecting Children From Toxic Chemicals
abstract: The cancellations, set to apply to pending and active grants, also affect research into “forever chemicals” contaminating the food supply.

title: The Lyrids Meteor Shower Is Peaking. Here’s How to Watch.
abstract: Active since last week, the shower is formed from a comet’s debris and is forecast to produce the most fireballs overnight.

title: Sludge Contaminated 10,000 Acres of Farmland. What Should Be Done?
abstract: For years a textile mill gave farmers its sewage sludge as free fertilizer. Today the land is full of “forever chemicals.”

title: He Was a Prophet of Space Travel. His Ashes Were Found in a Basement.
abstract: During his life, Willy Ley predicted the dawn of the Space Age with remarkable accuracy. How did his remains end up forgotten in a co-op on the Upper West Side?

title: Trump-Allied Prosecutor Sends Letters to Medical Journals Alleging Bias
abstract: An interim U.S. attorney is demanding information about the selection of research articles and the role of N.I.H. Experts worry this will have a chilling effect on publications.

title: A Fireball Near Mexico City Lit Up the Sky and the Internet
abstract: The glowing object was a bolide, fireballs that explode in a bright flash, according to experts. It streaked across Mexico’s predawn skies on Wednesday.
